awd_titl_txt: The quality control of oceanic carbon dioxide measurements: preparation and distribution of reference materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to continue to provide a mechanism for the quality control of ocean carbon dioxide measurements, in particular those that are made as part of international global programs. This will help to ensure that such measurements are comparable and accurate although made in different laboratories at different times, and will be an important factor in the design of a Global Ocean Observing System such as the proposed Global Ocean Acidification Observation Network, as well as playing a significant role in the quality control of ocean acidification measurements. 

To achieve this goal, the Scripps laboratory will prepare and certify reference materials for the following parameters of the oceanic carbon dioxide system in seawater: total dissolved inorganic carbon, total alkalinity, and hydrogen ion concentration, pH. The reference materials for total dissolved inorganic carbon and for total alkalinity will be based on natural seawater, sterilized, bottled, and analyzed using appropriate reference methods for these parameters. Reference materials for pH will be based on Tris buffers in synthetic seawater whose pH is directly related to measurements using classical Harned cells. In addition, the laboratory will distribute calibrated acid titrant for alkalinity measurements. The provision of reference materials to the international community helps to improve the overall quality of oceanic carbon data around the world both for field studies of the distribution of oceanic carbon, as well as for studies related to ocean acidification. Thus this effort is a significant US contribution to research infrastructure in this field.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this award, the Dickson group at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography continued their long-lived project to produce, calibrate, and distribute reference materials for the seawater CO2 system. Reference materials are homogeneous stable substances for which one or more properties have been established sufficiently well to calibrate a chemical analyzer, or to validate a masurement process.

Between 2017 and 2020, this grant enabled over 36,000 bottles of seawater (from about 30 separate batches of seawater) to be distributed to over a hundred different laboratories all around the world. This seawater had been collected originally off the coast of California, then filtered and treated further to remove micro-organisms. The treated seawater maintains a stable composition over a period of at least 3 years, making it well suited for use as a chemical reference material. Careful measurements are made at Scripps on samples from every batch of this stable seawater so as to certify the total dissolved inorganic carbon and total alkalinity appropriate to each batch of seawater. Once these calibrated samples have been distributed to other laboratories, it becomes practical for different scientific groups, working in different parts of the world and at different times, to make measurements that are calibrated against a uniform standard, and thus consistent one with another.

Once this can be achieved, it becomes practical to assemble a picture of the distibution of carbon dioxide in the world's oceans, and also to assess how the amount present in the oceans changes with time, i.e. reflecting uptake from the atmosphere whose own CO2 levels have been growing since the time of the Industrial Revolution.

This is, however, not the only value of such reference materials. They can also be used to improve seawater CO2 measurements for other related purposes. For example, many scientists are working to understand how organisms cope with the changing CO2 content of seawater, which lowers its pH somewhat in the process known as ocean acidification and can also affect how well shells and coral can grow. It is desirable that such studies can be clearly comparable from one laboratory to another, and using CO2 in seawater reference materials helps to ensure this.
